elements.title: Premium Property Visual Language: Elevated Trust Signals
elements.problem: Kris describes a premium property (57th St between Park & Lex, 11.5ft ceilings, rooftop, art collection). But the platform's visual language treats all listings the same — same card layouts, same typography, same badge system. Premium hosts need a visual language that mirrors the quality of their property and communicates trust at the level they expect. The Nudge book's concept of 'everything matters' applies to visual design: the visual quality of the platform is itself a choice architecture signal. A premium host seeing a generic interface will question whether the platform can attract premium guests.
elements.solution: Create a premium visual tier for high-value listings. (1) Use the deep purple palette (#31135D) for premium listing cards — this signals sophistication without adding new colors. (2) Typography shift: Use DM Sans at 600 weight for premium listing headlines (slightly more refined than Inter). (3) Photo treatment: Premium listings get full-bleed hero photos with the subtle purple gradient overlay from the style guide (--gradient-purple-dark). (4) Trust badges for premium listings: 'Verified Premium Property' using a gold/amber accent against the purple palette (use --accent-gold #D4A853 from proposed palette). (5) Spacing increases: Premium cards use --spacing-3xl padding instead of --spacing-2xl, giving content room to breathe — matching the 11.5ft ceilings Kris describes.

evidence.quote: It's on the nicest street in New York. It's on 57th between park and Lexington... the ceilings are about 11 and a half feet high.
evidence.insight: Kris communicates premium through spatial language: nicest street, specific cross-streets, ceiling height. The visual design must match this spatial premium with generous spacing and elevated typography.

evidence.quote: A good rule of thumb is to assume that everything matters. In many cases, the power of these small details comes from focusing people's attention in a particular direction.
evidence.insight: Visual details ARE choice architecture. A premium visual treatment focuses guest attention on quality, increasing booking likelihood and justifying higher pricing.

typography: DM Sans 600 for premium headlines at --text-xl (20px)
new_tokens_needed: --accent-gold (#D4A853) from proposed palette — not yet in production tokens

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: #31135D on #ffffff = 13.5:1 (passes). DM Sans 600 at 20px on white background meets large text requirements. Gold accent #D4A853 on white = 2.4:1 — use only for decorative elements, never for text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Premium listings visually separate from standard listings through denser color (deeper purple header) and more generous whitespace. The eye should register 'quality' before reading any content.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model calls for 'Premium-accessible: Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The premium visual tier must feel elevated but not gated — any host can aspire to it by improving their listing quality.

elements.title: Default Recommendation Visual Weight: Make the Nudge Visible
elements.problem: When the platform provides a default or recommendation (pricing, listing details, proposal response), the visual treatment must clearly signal 'this is the recommended choice' without appearing manipulative. The Nudge book's taxi tipping example shows that pre-calculated options with clear visual anchoring outperform blank inputs. But overly aggressive anchoring (like the 30% tip default) triggers reactance. The visual balance between 'clearly recommended' and 'not pushy' is critical.
elements.solution: Design a recommendation visual pattern. (1) The recommended option is displayed in a card with --secondary-purple border (2px, using --border-width-thick) and a subtle purple-tinted background (--bg-off-white). Alternative options use --border-color (standard gray) and --bg-white. (2) A small 'Recommended' badge in --secondary-purple with white text appears above the recommended card — never inside the card to avoid clutter. (3) The recommended number (price, date, etc.) uses --text-2xl (28px) and --font-weight-bold. Alternatives use --text-lg (18px) and --font-weight-medium. Size difference creates visual hierarchy without aggressive framing. (4) Allow one-tap acceptance of the recommended option and require additional taps for alternatives — friction as nudge.

evidence.quote: We kind of have a tool based on similar listings and we use location as well. We can kind of get a price estimate.
evidence.insight: Bryant frames the pricing tool as a recommendation, not a requirement. The visual pattern must match this tone: 'Here's what we recommend' with easy acceptance and easy override.

evidence.quote: Those who did install the technology were pleasantly surprised to learn that their tips increased... The screen appears only when the trip is over; the customer is ready to leave, and entering one's own amount requires some calculations and a couple extra steps. By contrast, just clicking one of the buttons is easy!
evidence.insight: The visual pattern must make the recommended option the easiest to select. Visual prominence + reduced friction = higher acceptance of good defaults. But reactance risk means avoiding aggressive anchoring.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: --secondary-purple (rgb(109,49,194)) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252,250,255)) = 5.8:1 (passes). Recommended badge: white text on --secondary-purple = 7.2:1 (passes AAA).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The recommended option must be visually 1.5x larger than alternatives through size, spacing, and color weight. The eye should land on the recommendation first and perceive alternatives as secondary.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' The recommendation pattern uses size and color hierarchy, not badges, icons, or animation to indicate preference.

elements.title: Protection Shield Visual System: Safety at a Glance
elements.problem: Kris's loss aversion about his art requires a visual system that communicates protection status instantly — within the 2-second System 1 assessment window. The current platform has no dedicated visual language for protection/safety status. Protection information is mixed with general listing data, requiring System 2 search to find it. For a loss-averse premium host, this visual absence IS the message: 'your property is not protected.'
elements.solution: Create a consistent protection visual system. (1) Protection status uses a distinct visual treatment: a shield icon (Feather icon 'shield') paired with a status color — --secondary-purple for 'fully protected,' --status-warning (#C4841D from proposed tokens) for 'action needed.' (2) The protection indicator appears in a fixed position on the active lease dashboard — top-right corner, always visible, never scrolls away. (3) Guest verification cards use a vertical purple stripe on the left edge (4px, --secondary-purple) to visually distinguish them from general information cards. (4) On hover/tap, the shield icon expands to show the full protection summary: credit check status, references verified, payment guarantee active, insurance level.

evidence.quote: I've got some really good art... how do you vet people?... we do credit check landlord references... we guarantee payments to you.
evidence.insight: Kris's anxiety demands an instant visual answer. A shield icon with 'Protected' status communicates in under 1 second what Bryant took 30 seconds to explain verbally.

evidence.quote: If a man sees a fly, he aims at it... etchings reduced spillage by 80 percent.
evidence.insight: A small visual signal (the fly in the urinal) changes behavior dramatically. A small protection shield icon changes the host's emotional state from anxious to assured. Visual nudges work because they require zero cognitive effort.

typography: Inter 600 at --text-sm (12px) for protection badge label
Inter 400 at --text-base (14px) for protection detail text
spacing: --spacing-md (12px) internal padding for protection detail card
new_tokens_needed: --status-warning (#C4841D) from proposed palette — not yet in production

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: Shield icon must be at least 24px (--icon-md) for visibility. --secondary-purple on white = 5.8:1 for text, adequate. Warning color #C4841D on white = 4.6:1, meets AA for large text only — use at --text-md (16px) minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The protection shield is always in the secondary scan position (top-right or directly below the heading). It must be visible without scrolling and must not compete with the primary content (listing details, earnings) for the first scan position.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate.' The shield icon is a universal trust signal that feels protective, not institutional. Using the purple palette instead of a generic green checkmark keeps it on-brand.

elements.title: Agent Presence Visual Pattern: Human Face in Digital Space
elements.problem: Kris's trust is built with Bryant (a person), not Split Lease (a platform). When Kris encounters the platform, there is no visual trace of Bryant. The Nudge book's concept of choice architecture emphasizes that the designer's invisible hand shapes experience. Making the agent's presence visible on the platform transfers human trust to digital trust. Without this visual bridge, the platform feels like a stranger's website.
elements.solution: Embed the agent's visual presence into the platform. (1) Agent avatar (--avatar-md, 48px, circular) appears in the dashboard header next to the host's name. Clicking reveals a contact card. (2) Agent-recommended items show a small avatar (--avatar-sm, 36px) and 'Bryant recommends' label. (3) The first-login experience opens with an agent welcome card: full photo, name, and a 1-sentence summary of what was discussed on the call. (4) Agent photo uses a subtle purple ring (2px --secondary-purple border) to visually distinguish from guest photos. (5) Agent contact info is always accessible via a floating action button (FAB) in the bottom-right corner — 48px minimum touch target, using --gradient-purple-button.

evidence.quote: I'm glad I got to talk. I know Christiana is, we've talked about you and I've mentioned before, but it's good to finally talk with you.
evidence.insight: Kris values the human connection with Bryant. 'Good to finally talk with you' implies built-up anticipation. The platform should sustain this connection visually.

evidence.quote: There are many parallels between choice architecture and more traditional forms of architecture... every trip to the bathroom creates an opportunity to run into colleagues.
evidence.insight: In building architecture, placing people near each other increases interaction. In digital architecture, placing the agent's face near the host's dashboard increases trust. Proximity is the nudge.

typography: DM Sans 600 at --text-md (16px) for agent name

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA: Agent FAB must meet 48px minimum touch target. Purple gradient button with white icon meets contrast requirements (tested).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The agent avatar is a supporting visual element — it should be visible but not dominant. It anchors trust without competing with primary content. The agent welcome card on first login is the exception: it dominates the view as the first interaction.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Warm, not cold. Trustworthy, not corporate.' The agent face literally warms the digital interface. A human presence transforms 'corporate platform' into 'someone you know helping you.'
